story.text:
This is Quinn. She’s a fourth grader. 


She loves fourth grade.
Most of her classmates also love the fourth grade.
When asked if they <label>belong at their school</label>, most of them say <label>yes</lable> —respected by other students and supported by adults at the school.
Let’s go to the next classroom over: Fifth graders.

Most fifth graders also said they <label>belong in their school</label>.


This sense of belonging at school is [incredibly important](https://www.edweek.org/leadership/a-universal-prevention-measure-that-boosts-attendance-and-improves-behavior/2024/04). It creates an environment where students do better academically and [stay in school](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html). It also helps them feel less sad and hopeless, and it might even help them be physically healthier as adults.

But there are many other things that kids like about elementary school.


We know this because, each year, schools around the country hire a company called Panorama Education to survey how their kids are doing—and Panorama shared the data with me. It includes responses from about 13 million students each year.

Everything isn’t perfect.


Most fourth- and fifth-graders say they aren’t <label>engaged in school</label>. They aren’t excited or interested about their classes, especially on the verge of graduating elementary school.

Many say their <label>school’s climate</label> isn’t ideal. 


They say the teachers aren’t always excited to be there, the school building isn’t great, and the rules aren’t fair.
But luckily, most of them say their <label>relationship with teachers</label> is pretty good. So even if school isn’t perfect, they have someone to go to.
Most students say they have <label>supportive relationships</label> in their lives—teachers, family members, and friends.
And overall, most students said they frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week — excitement, happiness, hope, love, and safety.

But for these fifth-graders, things are about to get a lot harder.


Their lives are about to shift dramatically—around them and within them.

Between ages 11 and 14, our brains become more malleable, like a block of clay softening to be resculpted. Scientists call this “brain plasticity.”


The first period of brain plasticity is from ages 0 to 3, when our brains [grow rapidly](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK234146/). We create new billions of brain cells and neural connections.  But this second period of plasticity, between 11 and 14, is when our neural connections are reorganized, writes developmental psychologist Laurence Steinberg in his book "[Age of Opportunity.](https://www.laurencesteinberg.com/books/age-of-opportunity)" 


**>> Timeline: 0 to 3 + 11 to 14**


The brain reorganization happens because we become highly sensitive to what we experience, both good and bad. The part of our brain that experiences pleasure is at its height during this period. Everything from candy to sex to punk music just *feels* better, while bad things like rejection or bullying feels worse.


One thing that will feel [especially good](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25770) is social interaction and acceptance. Steinberg writes that friends make them feel so good that it makes them want to take more chances and "do more reckless things."


These heightened experiences rewire our brains. Some neural connections get stronger, while others are pruned.


**>> Diagram**


Their brains will also develop a greater capacity for [self-direction](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth). So they’ll want more autonomy on what to wear, what to say, and how to spend their time.
So as they enter sixth grade, these kids will be especially sensitive to <label>social interactions</label> and they’ll want <label>more autonomy</label>.

But in sixth grade, most American kids are forced to change schools.


They are merged with students from other elementary schools and into something called middle school, throwing their <label>social lives into disarray</label>. In addition, they no longer have one teacher who cares for them, but a different teacher for each subject. 


Meanwhile, their <label>autonomy is yanked away</label>. They are required to switch classes constantly on an unyielding schedule. And the free time once known as “recess” is branded as an elementary school relic.

Remember how much fifth-graders felt like they <label>belonged in their school</label>?


Let’s see what happens in sixth grade.
Whoa. Sixth-graders are way less likely to feel <label>school belonging</label>.
And seventh-graders feel even less like they <label>belong in their school</label>.
The portion of students who are <label>engaged in school</label> absolutely plummets after fifth grade..
Their <label>relationship with teachers</label> gets significantly worse. Many say they don’t feel like their teachers care about them or respect them.

Most feel like their <label>school climate</label> isn’t ideal.


They believe their teachers are less excited; the physical space is less pleasant; and the rules are unfair.
Luckily, most students still say they have <label>supportive relationships</label>. But that support is usually family or friends, and no longer adults at school.
Ultimately, fewer students say they frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week.
If kids hate middle school so much, why does it exist?

Around 1900, most school districts had one school for kindergarten to 8th grade. But everyone from [college presidents](https://www.tojned.net/journals/tojned/articles/v04i01/v04i01-01.pdf) to the [National Education Association](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) argued that seventh graders should be attend a school that prepares them for high school: junior high school.


**>> Diagram**


However, what really pushed school districts to adopt junior high schools was overcrowding. Industrialization and immigration brought a huge influx of families to urban areas, crowding K-8 schools, according to a [RAND book](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) on middle schools. The popularity of junior high schools skyrocketed.


**>> Chart | Need data (rise of junior highs)**


Junior high was [basically](https://archive.org/details/educatingyoungad0000unse_q0p1/page/36/mode/2up?q=Mounting+Dissatisfaction) high school for younger kids, so in the 1960s [education scholars](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/19404476.2016.1165036) wanted to replace junior highs with something that caters to the specific needs of this age group. They wanted smaller group learning, better relationships with teachers, and more exploration. They called it middle school.


Slowly, more and more districts adopted the middle school model.


**>> Chart | [NCES](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d10/tables/dt10_097.asp)** 


But critics argued that most middle schools were [still run](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/461738) like junior high schools.
Research out of [New York](https://www.educationnext.org/stuck-in-the-middle/), [Florida](https://www.educationnext.org/the-middle-school-plunge/), and [several other](https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/edlabs/regions/west/Ask/Details/53) areas found that kids who attend middle schools learned less, while feeling lower levels of belonging and self esteem. So some school districts went back to the K-8 model. But [other research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0094119018300081) showed that kids in K-5 elementary schools actually do better because they’re not mixed with older kids, and that [makes up](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/498996) for the learning they lose in middle school.
After middle school, things stay pretty much the same as they transition to high school.
In high school, <label>school engagement</label> falls even further.
Very few students have strong <label>relationships with teachers</label>.
And their <label>sense of belonging</label> stays low.

We often treat middle schoolers as mid-evolution—no longer children, and waiting to be teens. It’s treated as halftime. But brain science is showing us that, if anything, middle school *is* the game.


"This phase is the last, best chance to raise thoughtful, ethical, kind, responsible people," writes school counselor Phyllis Fagell, author of “[Middle School Matters](https://phyllisfagell.com/middle-school-matters/).”


We often treat middle schoolers as irrational—as humans who need to grow up. So middle school has long been treated as a place to prepare elementary school kids for high school. But what if they are doing exactly what they need to be doing to survive? And what if we’re just failing to adapt to the radical changes a middle-schooler is experiencing? The authors of the [National Academy of Sciences book](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth) write:


> Adolescent brains are not simply “advanced” child brains or “immature” adult brains, but have evolved to meet the needs of this stage of life.


These days, the argument isn’t so much whether we should ban middle schools. Most education scholars say the jury is out, and that districts should do what is best for their students. Of course, funding still drives a lot of school decision-making. That means inertia often keeps us doing what we’ve always been doing. 


The idea that middle schools are mismatched for early adolescent kids is not new. It was one of the rationales for replacing junior highs. But the kids are clearly telling us things aren’t OK.

In a year, their brains will start caring way more about social interactions — exactly when they’re funneled off to a new school with new peers.


And they’ll also crave more autonomy — exactly when they’re shipped off to a bigger school with strict rules.
